newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Jakarta shares end higher on banks, blue-chips.
newsitem.headline: Jakarta shares end higher on banks, blue-chips.

text.p: Active buying in the banking sector and of selected big-capitalised stocks pushed Jakarta shares prices higher on Wednesday, brokers said.
The Jakarta Composite Index rose 5.46 points, or 0.88 percent, to close at 626.27 points after touching a low of 620.74. Gainers led losers by 55 to 51, with 66 counters unchanged.
Brokers said market sentiment was likely to stay firm on Thursday as buying interest in banks and several big and medium-capitalised counters remained high.
But brokers said profit-taking could hold the index back on Thursday, with some investors looking for short-term gains.
They said trading was boosted on Wednesday when a number of overseas buyers entered the market during the afternoon.
Newly-listed Bank Negara Indonesia (BNI), BDNI and Bank International Indonesia were among favoured stocks, brokers said.
BNI topped the active list with 26.6 million shares changing hands. Its price was unchanged at 1,275 rupiah after earlier rising to 1,300 rupiah.
Brokers said the current downtrend in deposit rates among major banks while lending rates remained stable had triggered fresh buying in the bank sector.
Bank International Indonesia rose 200 rupiah to 2,475 rupiah on a volume of around 10 million shares, while BDNI rose 50 rupiah to 2,450 rupiah on 2.4 million shares.
Blue-chips telecommunications firm Telkom and international telephone operator Indosat were also actively traded on what brokers said was bargain-hunting.
Telkom rose 100 rupiah to 4,025 on 1.8 million shares. Brokers said it was partly due to market talk of a possible higher dividend by the end of the year.
A company official denied the rumours saying the firm planned to announce the dividend at its annual general meeting scheduled for April.
Indosat rose 100 rupiah to 6,425 rupiah on 1.9 million shares on what brokers said was bargain-hunting. This was also in line with its overnight closing price in New York.
Shipping firm Berlian Laju Tanker fell 25 rupiah to 4,700 rupiah after rising to 4,900 rupiah on a volume of 7.8 million shares on what brokers said was profit-taking.
"It rose earlier following a company announcement it would discuss equity participation in other firms at its extraordinary general meeting in January," a local broker said.
